The art historian tries in retrospect to retrace a development in art that is inherently consistent with the artefacts of history. He can demonstrate that art is always a forward-moving process but that within that development there are also contradictions. Art is a step from A to B. B can take A a stage further, but can also be directed against A. In the same way artists draw inspiration from the art of their forefathers, as witnessed in the Renaissance artist's preoccupation with Antiquity. Artists of all periods must in some manner probe the depths of the universal world of art. That an artist should systematically concern himself with the cosmic entirety of art is, however, quite new. Artists do of course build up their knowledge around the art of the past. But the musée imaginaire, the consideration of the whole spectrum of art has hitherto always been the work of historians, cultural historians or biographers (e.g. Vasari). There was always a clear-cut division of roles. Here the scientist-prophet, delving into the past, there the artist, sensing the past to visualize the present and future. Take the example of Picasso and his involvement with Renaissance art, the many variations on a borrowed theme in his own paintings. But for the artist drawing inspiration from the past, or casting his eye back, the ingredients of change have always been crucial in his quest to define his own self and his own artistic drive, with the other work of art acting as a catalyst. How did Romberg come to embark upon this artistic venture involving the whole of art history?

In doing so, he not only pays homage to his predecessors but also reinterprets their legacies, using them as a foundation to build his own artistic identity. This synthesis of historical awareness and personal expression is what makes his venture into art history so compelling and relevant in today's context.

The museum curator believes in the power and fascination of the works of art he administers. He seeks to highlight their aura, their expressive quality without denying their cognitive characteristics. He is familiar with their various meanings, uses, subject matter and stylistic approaches. He can distinguish between a medieval altarpiece, an object of worship and an impressionistic landscape designed to serve a "decorative" function. He must bear in mind the background and artistic impulse behind any single work of art. He has learnt from practical, daily contact with art that every work of art obeys its own set of laws that challenge pre-existing conventions in art. Goethe, for instance, to take a negative example, misunderstood Romanticism because he sought to comprehend Romantic art on the basis of the very artistic precepts that the Romantics were fighting against, the classical criteria of a Winkelmann or a Meng. The historian endeavours to recognize the guiding principle which underlies a work (and not the reverse). For this he employs the widest range of methods, including a study of sources, stylistic comparison or iconographical investigation. In doing so he has constantly to remain open-minded in his attitude to any particular work. In dubio pro reo says the legal formula; here one might say in dubio pro arte. We live in an area of inventories, final analysis, exact science, whys and wherefores, a time in which encyclopaedic knowledge has become very much the rule. Correct. And then I begin the post-pictum works, which are for me a sort of private celebration of what I have done, and my post-pictum lead me into new work. A propos the post-pictum sketches, those that I did after (according to) my work, my assistants asked me why I was doing them, and I answered, 'as gossip'. Why do you bother with a book like Key Buildings in the 20th Century, written by someone you don't even know and that you took from the bookstore by pure chance? Or your work on architectural plans from other books on architecture, for instance Buildings Footprints, in which all the plans are reproduced on the same scale, from the Parthenon to the church of Ronchamp (Notre Dame du Haut) by Le Corbusier? Could you tell us what you do with these?

I find value in exploring works like *Key Buildings in the 20th Century* and *Buildings Footprints* because they offer a wealth of knowledge and inspiration. Even if I don't know the authors personally, their insights into architectural history and theory can provide a deeper understanding of the built environment. By analyzing these plans and structures, I can draw connections between different architectural styles and movements, which enriches my own artistic practice. It's about engaging with the past to inform the present and future, allowing me to reinterpret and respond to these influences creatively.

When I saw the book in the bookstore, I thought that it was funny that someone could decide today that these are the noteworthy buildings. I had a sudden insight that connected these works with the works I did in the 70's, those pictorial analyses of famous paintings that I displayed as artistic works in their own right. But in the 70's I chose the works subjectively, so I called them 'an emotional analysis of the history of art'. This time, I thought that I would take a whole book in which I chose nothing, where my choice is irrelevant, that I would get a 'readymade', but an impersonal one, because someone else chose the works for me. Again, we are dealing with the question of a small versus a large degree of freedom. These are my boundaries: to make art out of something that is neither art nor contemporary.

The works that I did before this project were almost plans of houses as viewed from above. I have stated many times that I want to lift architecture from the floor and place it on the wall, just as they took pictures from the wall and put them on the floor. Here again we have an element of reversibility: where, then, is the drawing? the architecture? the decorativeness? What happens when I cancel the functions of something functional and turn it into something ornamental on the wall? These are questions which start a dialogue, a discussion on whether art today can restrict itself to expression or whether it can also be a discussion of all that has occurred from the Renaissance to the present.
